text: Urban belly is a great place to get dinner with a group of friends in a upscale casual setting, and serves as a good introduction to Asian fusion.  Here's a quick rundown of all the dishes we tried: Phat rice - greasy goodness; would be a perfect post hangover meal! Urban belly ramen- there portion was huuuuuge and the broth was flavorful and packed with vegetables. The noodles were so-so Pea shoot Madras curry rice- one of two vegetarian options. The dish was a bit dry and I think the curry portion was really just the powder and not the actual curry  Wok fried rice cakes with shrimp- so, so good! The stir fry sauce was equal parts sweet, salty, umami packed, and spicy. The shrimp was juicy and flavorful and all the components of this dish went together like a dream  Rice and salad bowl with BBQ pork belly - the picked vegetables in this packed a real punch. The soft boiled egg was cooked perfectly and so was the pork. A must try! We came here on a Friday night and while bellyQ next door was packed, this place was relatively empty and our group of 6 was able to quickly situate ourselves at one of the many wooden tables in the outdoor seating area.  Urban Belly does not have full service. You have to order at the counter, take a number, and your order to brought to your table. The menu is about half an A4 sheet, with a little more than a dozen appetizer and entree options, a kiddy menu, desserts, and libations. I thought that it was a clever to have a whittled down menu which would not be overwhelming. Within the entree options, there are rice dishes, noodles dishes, and ramen. Of course, the menu isn't very inclusive of dietary preferences, but I don't think urban belly was a place intended for those with restrictive diets. One of my dining companions was a vegetarian, and he chose the Madras curry pea shoot dish (one out of two possible choices). I went with the wok fried rice cakes with shrimp, my boyfriend picked the rice and salad bowl with BBQ pork, and my other friends picked the urban belly ramen and the phat rice, along with a plate of the pork and coriander dumplings. All of our portions were huge for the price! Service was really quick! My boyfriend got his order a couple of seconds after he got back to our table after placing the order. All of our orders were at our table under ten minutes. The seating area is really well done up, with string lights, and a wall of Hebru Brantley's art. The tables can be a bit grimy, and we had to all the staff to clean the previous party's litter from our table. The restaurant is in a slightly off traffic location, near a few parks and the green line L station. Overall, I'd highly recommend this place for a quick, cheap (under $15) and flavor packed meal!

I'm a fan of the adjoining restaurant, Belly Q. Not a fan of Urban Belly. For the overall price we paid, there was too much serving ourselves. The food was decent, but it was just too much of us doing the work. Maybe I'm getting too old fashioned for these counter service places. I don't mind if I order from the counter and have to grab a couple things, but I made four trips from the counter to our table to serve our family of three (all drinks, utensils, spare bowls, ) etc. If I'm going to put in that much work, I'll just cook for our family at home.

My wife and I eat here at least once a week.  I've always wanted to try other things on the menu but when u love what you order, why change it up.  I always do the phat rice and she usually gets the urbanbelly ramen.

Wheat berry bibimbap is on point! Might not be everybody's cup of tea, but for this Korean gal - a little kimchi, whole half of an avocado, pickled cucumbers, tofu, myriad of green bits, even some eggplant --- all smothered in gochujang is perfect for a hearty and delicious meal.  I was hesitant about the wheat berry base but it's hearty and I kind of prefer to rice now. Quick and easy place, great post workout option.

Really had high expectation after reading the reviews and all, but it came up short for me unfortunately. Decor is really nice, love it at first sight with outdoor seating.  Urban belly ramen broth is little watery comparing to miso based broth you'll find in other ramen shop. Main disappointment was the amount of noodles, leaving me still hungry wanting for more... Phat rice was good, but I find that too salty and had to keep drinking water during and afterwards. Also ordered a special $3 fries with curry mayo and that turned out to be the best among the three things we ordered. Recommend Joyee if you like Malaysian Singaporean Chinese dishes.
Like the food but the service has gone to shit. The place was empty & it took forever to get my food I use to eat here all the time but never again. Sad #westloop

$14 for ramen, I expect good flavor and good portions.  The soup was flavorful, but literally had three bites of noodles and it was gone.  Two good sized pork strip, but one was completely made of fat with absolutely no meat on it.  Friend got the phat noodle which was okay, portions were good but the flavor was somewhat off putting. The atmosphere and decor were nice, but won't be coming back for the food.

I'm usually a bit skeptical on Asian fusion places but I thought the curry soup that I got was quite delicious. It was the right consistency and flavor and had a lot of noodles. I love curry soups in general so this was a good fit for me. Some of the other items on the menu looked a bit frou frou so I wasn't sure, but so far, positive opinions of this place. They have a nice outdoor seating area where you can get all the utenstils, napkins and water that you want outside. The area that it's in is a little bit odd, next to some parks and next to the L station.

Asian fusion for sure. Don't expect traditional flavors here. That said, the food is flavor-packed. I got the ramen, and the broth was spicy and rich. Seating is kind of hidden in the back with a nice,casual atmosphere. Good for groups.

I'm a little bit on the fence about this place. I will have to say the rating is a bit inconclusive right now, but I'm going to give it a 3/3.5.  I want to give it a higher rating simply because their happy hour special is amazing. $5 pitcher of frosty Kirin??? HELLOOOO. I would come here just to drink.  On the other hand, since it's not really a bar and more of a restaurant, I have to say that the food is kind of.....interesting. My friend ordered the ramen and it looked just mediocre. The Charsiu was overcooked and a bit big/unwieldy. Which I feel, shouldn't be a descriptor used with Charsiu.  I got the recommendation to try their rice cake pad Thai which was a very odd combination indeed. I absolutely LOVE rice cake in all forms and this just felt kind of out of place. The sauce didn't even really taste like pad Thai at all. It was like someone put some sambal on top of some rice cakes wth cilantro and mint. IDK guys.  For now- I highly recommend the happy hour drink specials but maybe tread a bit carefully with the food.

Order up front and shimmy over to the back for a communal type setting. Water and utensils are on the tables as well so just help yourself.  I went here for lunch w a friend and ordered the Ramen Jr, Belly dog, Phat rice, and beef & cheddar dumplings. The dumplings were deep fried and the taste of melted cheese with the beef is not too bad. Ramen Jr was still quite large of a serving, noodles were just chewy enough. However the soup tasted too much of lemon grass; I felt I was eating tom yum soup. Belly dog is also not bad tasting but  it was overflowing with cilantro toppings. The fries were pretty good. No comment on the phat rice since my friend ate all of it.  Overall experience was average. Passable.
Great selection, great prices, prompt service.  Carry out is great & you dont have to fight for a parking spot.

Yum!!! my First dinner in chicago was a success! don't be afraid to ask questions. the cashier is SO helpful and may even offer you samples.  Things i've discovered: the spiked lemonade was too sweet for me. Wheat berries are kind of like a thick coated grain, similar to brown rice in my opinion. The ramen was sweet too. I would say the ramen broth is less of a ramen broth and more of a tom yum broth, sweet and tangy and not at all what i'd like in my ramen. thankfully i didn't order the ramen for myself :) I ordered the phat noodles and was very happy with my choice: it came with three types of meat and was perfectly flavored sweet and salty. My friends enjoyed their rice bowls, and i would say the portion is perfect for one person, not too much and not too little. Restrooms are clean and interior is very trendy and spacious. definitely a must visit! If the weather is nice, take pictures out on the patio!

It's not bad. The ramen isn't as good as High Five, but for a quick lunch fix, it was tasty and filling. A little spicy, a little sweet. The pork was very well done, it fell apart in your mouth, but the fatty portion had just a bit of crisp to it. Noodles had good bite, though it probably could have used more noodles.

I loved the interior! Service was good too. I got the phat rice. It was a little challenge eating out of the narrow banana shaped bowl.   Rice was a little too greasy for me n dish was overall too salty for my liking. The beef, pork and chicken were flavorful but didn't work so well with the lemon grass fried rice. I think I would enjoy it more if the 3 toppings were served with white rice as that would mk it less salty n draw out the flavors of the toppings. The vodka with passion fruit lemonade was good tho.

Urbanbelly is everything I hope for when I'm in the mood for hearty Asian fusion. It's the more casual portion of the restaurant (Belly Q being the fancier, sit down side), so it's order at the counter and grab your own seating, which is a-ok with me!  I absolutely love the Rice & Salad bowl with tofu. The pickled veggies and perfectly soft boiled egg make this dish a knock out. My one tiny critique is that they use some type of herb/green that tastes really funky to me, but no matter how many times I've tried to ask what it is (so that I can ask if they can please leave it out), no one is able to tell me. Not a huge deal, but it would make it a 5-star place if they had someone who knew the ingredients like the back of their hand.  The BF has tried the Ramen, Pho and Phat Rice, and can't pick a favorite because he loved them all.  The PB&J dessert with chunky peanut butter, handmade jam and delicious soft serve is also swoon worthy. It's not a large portion, but it can easily be shared between two to satisfy a sweet tooth. It's been featured as one of the best casual desserts in Chicago.  Overall, I really love Urbanbelly and would gladly come back, even if I do have to pick some of the greens out of my bowl ;)

I really like this place. I'm always scoping out the next place where I can eat tasty ramen/noodles. Although me and a group of friends came here for the $2 tacos but was bummed out when we were informed it was actually going on at their other location only. Nonetheless I had the coconut curry pho which was delicious. My friends had the dumplings , maple glazed mini donuts, and kids chicken rice. All dishes were really good. Service was okay. I got my food pretty fast and so did one of my friends, but the other who ordered dumplings had to wait a little longer than we did. Also I'd like to mention that I loved the atmosphere of the place. Very natural and peaceful. There's a sage wall that's pretty cool.
Got the to go order with 1 of 3 items on it missing. Life must be difficult not being able to count to 3

I really like this place it's quite trendy. My bf has been on a ramen kick so we tried it. It's great they have free parking and nice outdoor seating. The service is great and the ambiance. It was an experience like no other! My bf and I ordered the Urban Belly Ramen, Phat Noodle and Pork and Cilantro pot stickers. The Ramen serving size was huge and flavorful. My bf said it was too spicy but not to me. The phat Noodle was flavorful sweet with a couple different types of meant piled to the top of the bowl and full of noodles at the bottom. I also ordered some kind of lemonade I believe it was passion fruit. It was ok super sour it didn't really have the flavor of what ever it was supposed to be. The food came out in a good amount of time. They also had self served water. If you are looking for a place that serves you they don't. You pay for your food and then sit down but they do bring you your food. Over all, I would go back again. I recommend! The serving are huge so you probably will have left overs.

Went here for the first time a few weeks ago. Heads up, even though this is in West Loop, it's on the FAR WEST side of west loop, so beware if you're thinking about walking to this from say ogalvie's station. Once arriving, you start ordering your food at the counter. They have a lot of options from ramen (their specialty) to rice dishes to curries. Heads up, I'd recommend getting the 1/2 bowl order of ramen because it's massive. I couldn't even finish the 1/2 bowl order I did. After ordering, you get a number and take a seat. The seating is bench style, seat yourself. The décor is nice, they have this "plant-wall" where plants are planted all over this area on the wall, makes a good spot for group pictures ;). Overall, the food was great, it made it nice you don't have to make reservations, you can just seat yourself. It wasn't busy when we got there (6pm), but it started filling up later on. This is a good place for group dinners or when you're not sure how many people are going to show up (hence the NO reservations required). You know those people who never RSVP but show up.. looking at you =P. I'd come back here for sure. City winery is not far away so it'd be nice to go from one to the other for a wine flight.

Such an eclectic combination of ramen dishes. I got the Urban Belly and added beef to it...it was perfect. The broth was an orangey goodness, and kinda supple...which I like. The passion lemonade with mezcal was amazing for just $5. I would've given 5 stars, but I had so much broth with no noodles left....they can do a better noodle to broth ratio. Buttttt...I'd go back in a heartbeat! Great service too!

DO NOT OVER ORDER. Yes I know you're hungry, it all sounds so good. It is. But seriously pace yourself. You can always go back to the counter and order more if your stomach keeps rumbling. 1. You order first and pay at the counter. They give you a number. You sit at a table. You wait patiently. 2. If you order the ramen you will love it. But you order the small version because you're smart and want to save room to drink at the other bars up the street. 3. You order Phat Rice and share with a friend that isn't weirded out by sharing food. 4. You order the Pork Dumplings and share them with one another person that doesn't have that weird aversion to cilantro #SoapPatrol 5. You enjoy all that you have eaten, laughing and making new friends at long community tables. 6. You come back and leave a review because you're cool like that.
You got to try the Coconut Pho. Its one of my favorite lunch dishes in Chicago. The atmosphere is inviting as well!
Good, spicy food. Food was served pretty quickly, almost when we went to the community seating area.

The ramen was really meh for me and I wish I could have given them a higher rating. It was quite obvious that this place was opened by a non Asian owner as the broth and everything was too rich for my liking. Once you go inside the restaurant, you pretty much order on the board and and pick whatever you like and they give you a number and you find your seat. I kinda wish there was more pictures on what I will be ordering versus ordering on the board and not having any pictures. After I got my order, I sampled the broth and it was hella rich and a bit salty and I really wish they let me choose the choice of pork belly cut ( Chashu or Kukuni) if you don't know the different cuts in terms of ramen then you are not eating the right ramen. Nonetheless, it came with Chashu cut and it was sooo fatty. So I do eat pork belly but not when there's more fat than the meat itself. I pretty much consumed an entire lard in my stomach. The portion size wasn't big compared to how much broth they gave you. I was forced to order extra noodles because I was still hungry and again too much broth. There's other places you can try but I will not come back again since I have other options .

So far this is my favorite ramen in the city. Generous portion of excellent noodles with a broth distinct from others I've tried. Pork belly is well seasoned and a perfect addition. Highly recommended.

I want to like this place, but when I went here I got salmonella poisoning. I spent the next two days cramping up and getting chills from their food. Even the other person I went with got the same symptoms as me! On the third day I still had a few minor cramps. It hurt to move, and I didn't appreciate the fact that I had things to do those days. I should have known right away that there was something suspicious about how quickly the food got to our table.  In terms of how the food tasted - it was over-spiced. If I did a blind taste-test, I could not have identified what I was eating. That's something I expect myself to do and not a restaurant. What I ordered didn't taste or look like chicken... but it was. However, I did appreciate the aesthetic and ambiance of the interior. That was my favorite part. Watch out for how fast your food gets to the table at this place, guys.

Came back here and ordered the Urbanbelly ramen and phat rice to split between two again. This time I didn't find either dish to be that great--if anything it merely served as comfort food to have on a warm winter day at the outdoor dining area. The phat rice was also on the sweet side, which I dislike with savory dishes. $30 meal including tip.

The food was amazing, they don't have a waitresses service you order at the counter and they take it to you. We went for lunch and had a great time, the dumplings flavor was amazing and the junior ramen was more than enough.

Honestly one of the best restaurant experiences I've had anywhere in Chicago. The food is incredible - the coconut curry pho is among the best things I've ever eaten, my partner's pork belly ramen was a close second, and the sweet potato dumplings are the perfect sweet/savoury combo - and was brought to our table within ten minutes of ordering. The staff are so kind and attentive, and the service is fantastic. This place definitely gets slightly overshadowed by bellyQ nextdoor, but it's honestly the real gem.
I really wanted to love this place, but I'm not a huge fan of communal seating and the mushroom pho was average. It was a decent experience overall, but I probably won't go back.

I love everything about Urbanbelly. It is causal, the atmosphere is great, and the waitstaff is incredible. I have been to various Urbanbelly locations and tried about everything on the menu. There is not a single thing that I dislike about this restaurant. Every time I'm in Chicago, I make sure to eat at Urbanbelly.

Communal seating is generally a turnoff for me, but it's a complete non-issue at Urbanbelly during lunch time.  Our group of 5 had our pick of tables, and the restaurant slowly became more busy as the afternoon approached.  The restaurant is adjacent to Belly Q, a more formal sit-down restaurant. I like the counter service style too.  Your order and pay at the counter, they'll bring your food out to you at the table.  It's freaky fast, but this is no Jimmy John's. The Phat Noodles were delicious!  Everything is in this bowl:  lemongrass chicken, pork belly, braised beef, noodles, and veggies.  I loved the thickness of the noodles and all of the spices.  I went wild with the two sauces at the table, a hot sauce and a mystery sauce that had no label.  Most of the entrees were in the $12-13 range, and the Phat Noodles were worth every penny. I arrived here borderline hangry, but still had leftovers to take home for lunch the next day.  Those little bowls are bigger than they look! I tried all of the potstickers, and the pork and cilantro were generally the favorite.  I can only say good things about the beef and cheddar and the sweet potato potstickers though!  I did think that these are overpriced though.  $7 gets you 4 potstickers, which is hard to share with a group. Sundays are BYOB, with no corkage fee, but I completely forgot.  Luckily, they serve a variety of bottled beer and cocktails.  There's a "create your own" cocktail option, for $5.  When was the last time you got a GOOD cocktail for $5?  Try the Vietnamese iced coffee with the Japanese whiskey. We ended our trip here with the cinnamon donut dessert.  It wasn't life-changing, but it definitely hit the spot.

3.5 stars really I loved the space...communal seating, dark wood balanced by the live plant wall. Wide open space, modern feel.  I'm a sucker for good dumplings and their potstickers were delicious. Our group of 5 shared the pork/cilantro, sweet potato, beef/cheddar and the kid's burger dumplings. I loved them all, with the sweet potato taking a slight lead as I loved the texture and taste just a little bit more than the other.   I opted for the Urbanbelly Ramen for my main and honestly, I wasn't blown away.  I didn't get that clouds-open-angel-light-shining moment that I have felt with other ramen joints. There's a generous portion of pork belly (yum) and it's on the tad spicy side. It was ok, just didn't really hit the spot.  I tried some of the phat rice, it was good, a little smooshed.  But it tasted even better when you add some of the house soy/vinegar sauce.   They offer beer and even a beer slushie.  But our group dined on a Sunday where it's BYOB, no corkage fee. Yay for the Bubbly!    Service was friendly and the food was brought out to us really fast.  I don't know if that's the norm or because they just opened and there were only a few diners there.  Big portions--enough for leftovers!
This is my go too when I'm not feeling well. The ramen hits the spot and they are great with to go orders.  The dumplings are delicious too.

Before Urban Belly, the only thing I knew about bellies came from Dr. Seuss who wrote a whole book about bellies (Sneeches on the Beaches), "The Star-Bellied Sneetches had bellies with stars. The Plain-Belly Sneetches had none upon thars..."  Urban Belly, like Dr. Seuss, defies characterization. The restaurant serves Asian inspired street food but you wouldn't call it pan-Asian. It is casual and quick, but it's not fast food. My favorite, must-have, can't-leave-without item is the Katsu Rice Noodle Cake Soup Bowl. The soup is very spicy but rich with complex flavor. The chewy noodles are mixed in with some kind of dumplings and the chicken katsu. It's a "must order". I also like the eggplant appetizer which is on the sweet side offset by vinegar but very fresh and light. Everything else is good but these are the standout items for me. Much more dubious than the food is the Kirin Frozen Beer Slushy.  Never had it. It's probably great but I'm not up for trying it. The restaurant sits at the peaceful end of the Randolph Street Food Conniption, closer to the United Center than the Loop. There is usually parking and never a wait. It sits alongside BellyQ, a more conventional and upscale restaurant, but I'm not sure the food is more tasty there. At Urban Belly, the décor is relaxed and the tables and highboys all have stools. Lots of distressed wood gives the place a handmade feel, and the huge wall photo of horses is just confusing. Still, you'll love the soup and probably won't notice the other stuff. There is a terrific garden to eat in when the weather accommodates.

Pre Blackhawks game dinner with the family and I was so excited to come here! The rest of my family has been here before and I have heard nothing but good things. Everything had such intense flavors it was all so delicious. We got just about everything on the menu to share between the four of us and everything had decent portion sizes so it worked out perfectly. I really loved the mint matcha iced tea I had. In terms of the food the best thing we had was the pork and cilantro dumplings and the PB&J soft serve ice cream dessert. If you are in the west loop give this place a shot!

I have to say that I was pretty excited to try Urban Belly! I love that their menu is extensive enough, but not overwhelming! Indecisive foodies like me hate massive menus! :)  For my first time there, I was torn between ordering ramen or getting a rice dish. I needed to be filled up, so I went with a rice dish! I ordered the Phat Rice which has lemongrass chicken, pork belly, braised beef and pineapple. We also ordered the pork and cilantro dumplings. My hubby got the wheat bibimbap.  The service was good and our food came out promptly. The Phat Rice was very yummy! I loved the pineapple, it complimented the various meats in the rice! Tasty! The pork and cilantro dumplings were good, but nothing special. I really can't wait to go back and try the ramen! I've heard good things about it!  The atmosphere is nice. It has a cool design, communal tables, and a fresh vibe.

This is our go to for a quick and easy meal.  I love their ramen, seasoned and spiced so you really do not have to add anything.  Rice dishes are all good, you cannot go wrong there. Check out their specials, we have never been disappointed.  If they bring their Belly Shack menu here I may never leave.

My family came here before a Blackhawks game. My mom and I got the phat noodles, my dad got a coconut curry pho, and my sister got the ramen. My mom loved her's, but mine was too spicy for me (I can't handle any amount of spicy). Everyone really enjoyed their dish. I tried but I couldn't get into mine. I asked them for a less spicy dish suggestion, and ended up getting the pork and cilantro dumping instead. They didn't even charge me! The dumplings were amazing. Great restaurant, even better staff. Only warning: all their food is some level of spicy. It's great if you can handle it, but on a scale of 1-10 I like my spice at a -2, so not for me.

Good food, huge portions for a decent price. BellyQ has a nicer ambiance and fancier food/beverage options but Urbanbelly is more bang for your buck. They have weeknight happy hour specials that are hard to beat in Chicago.. $5 Kirin PITCHERS! Not just pints. As vegetarians, I tried the mushroom pho and my boyfriend had the pea shoot rice bowl. Mine was good although a little too 'bourbon' tasting for me..  not sure what caused it to taste like that. We both agreed the pea shoot bowl was the better choice. Spiced edamame on the side was delicious too. And I had plenty of leftovers! I would definitely recommend this place and hope to go back.

There's a nice casual vibe at this restaurant that permeates to the food.  Everything about this place is unfussy -- you order at a counter, sit on benches, etc.  But the food is good and made for sharing -- the dumplings are a particular favorite.  Also, on Sunday nights it is BYO.  The opportunity to share a nice bottle of wine on the large outdoor seating area is a particularly nice option in the warmer months.

Urbanbelly WAS amazing.  It was an absolute favorite of ours.  Why they have changed the menu is totally beyond me.  We have tried the new menu and had the restaurant recreate our old favorites.  All has been a disaster since moving to the Randolph space.  We are so disappointed.  I still crave their old menu like crazy.

Delicious! We live around the block and pick up from here frequently. The sweet potato dumplings are the bomb, and the pineapple pork rice is amazing. I do wish they had a few more options on the menu but all the same this place is solid.
Ramen was good and it came fast.  The guy at the register was super helpful and nice as it was our first time. Overall,  I'd definitely come back,  just wish they had more drink options.

Went here on a sunday i like the fact thst its byob on Sundays. Also there wasnt a cork fee if i remember correctly. The food was nothing special. The pad thai was just alright. I liked the atmosphere and decor

Stellar dishes that hit the spot! Their communal tables make it a delight to enjoy a meal . If you are not into seating with strangers , order take out. I really enjoyed the ambiance, food, service, and set up on the table.   The staff was very nice. After he took my order asked me if I belonged to the gym next door. WAC and gave me a discount which I didn't even know about. Hint hint! West loop athletic club members.
Really liked the food and the atmosphere here.  Definitely try their Pho and lemon chicken rice.

Wok Fired Rice Cakes...no other words to say but "amazing". They do not hold back on the shrimp in this dish, and they are jumbo sized. The sauce really makes this dish. I'm not sure what they put in that sauce, but they could sale this sauce by itself. That's how good it is. I found myself sadly "scarfing" my entire plate down, because I just couldn't get enough. The dish is amazing, the customer service was good and the food was freshly prepared and came out within 10 minutes of being seated. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and its at a good location right on the corner of ashland and randolph. When the spring time hits, I would love to go there more frequently during lunch and sit in their outdoor area and eat.

I was so excited to finally try this restaurant. Upon entering the staff looked irritated that we did not know how the ordering process worked. First time and def last time. It was OK but nothing special. We ordered two orders of the sweet potato and maple dumplings, not what we were expecting! Tasteless, hard and flat. Next course Ramen Jr which was just OK. The best dish was the pineapple and pork combo which was very flavorful. The featured dessert was donuts and ice cream and it was again OK. Terrible parking lot. Restaurant was very clean as were the restrooms.

Grabbed a bite here after attending a concert at the Bottom Lounge. We ordered at a counter and then had a seat and the food was brought out fairly quickly. We tried to Ramen Jr ($8), which is the smaller bowl of the Urban Belly Ramen ($12), and the Coconut Curry Pho ($13) that was on special. Both were great in their own way. The Ramen Jr had a nice spice to it and the pork belly was so tender. If you like coconut curry, than the coconut curry pho would be a great choice. Both bowls were actually the same size and they were a good sized portion, so I would highly recommend getting the Ramen Jr, especially if you are planning on ordering any apps.
Don't get the Asian Bolognese. Its just spaghetti with meat sauce. It sucked.
Ordered ramen for delivery, everything arrived neatly packaged and nothing needed to be warmed up. Not to mention out of this world delicious.

We ordered delivery to our hotel. The food showed up pretty late. They provided no utensils for us to eat with. Got the Urban Belly Ramen and the Asian Bolognese. Asian Bolognese was too sweet for my taste. Urban belly Ramen was ok, but nothing too exciting. Maybe my experience would be different if I ate in the restaurant.... especially if we had silverware or chopsticks. I can't tell you how hard it is to eat noodles with your fingers.

This place has great ramen. I got the Ramen Jr. which was more than enough for one person, so I have to imagine the regular size is enormous. Their cocktails are actually pretty good too. It's casual dining - you order at a counter and it's communal seating, and this location also has a nice patio to enjoy during the warmer months. I'll definitely be back.
Went here for lunch and it was really good. I got the ramen and I'd have to say it's neck and neck with strings and high five ramen.

Ramen was decent, phat rice was decent. Service was pretty good too. Belly lost stars because when I went to sit out on the patio, it was empty of people but almost every table was some type of dirty. We found one table that wasn't sticky or full of napkins and garbage to sit at. I thought it was odd too that a sever kept circling past the tables and not thinking to wipe them down. I would probably come back again and hopefully it would be a little more clean.
Friendly staff, awesome food. Definitely want to come back again! We went out of our way to come here (we live near the loop) and I'm glad we decided to do so!

Yum yum yum! After a day of dancing I needed something hearty. Thank goodness this place was nearby! Got the urban belly phat noodles. Damn! It had all types of meat. Beef, chicken and pork lol. Just what I needed. It was delicious! The flavors went well and then to top it off, they had a good array of sauces. The noodles were nice and thick. I really enjoyed my meal (my plate was empty lol... Ate that Thang like whoa).  Then I got the donuts! That was okay! It was a nice little dessert but I definitely was full. It's a relaxed environment and you can eat indoors or outdoors. Great food. :)

Urbanbelly never disappoints! Everytime I come here I try something new and it's always super delicious, and refreshing. What I like most about this place is their quality consistency. I have never left unsatisfied! The flavor combos are always on point.

Urbanbelly was good, but pretty underwhelming for its hype. Decent service, decent food, decent price for a restaurant in West Loop. We got the Urbanbelly Ramen, which included curry-like-based broth, ramen noodles, pork belly, and a soft boiled egg. The bowl may look large, but most of it was just soup. The flavor of the broth was pretty strong/tasty, and slightly spicy, but I'm finding it hard to describe what the flavor actually was. The pork belly and egg were both prepared nicely.

I had the distinct pleasure of trying the Urbanbelly Ramen and the Pork and Pineapple. The ramen was well balanced, the broth spicy but not overbearing. It was creamy without being heavy, and the noodles held up well in the broth. The pineapple and pork combo was simply a delight - sweet and savory! The garnishes used in the dish were well received, the pork belly cubes tender and flavorful, with the sweet pineapple rounding out the dish nicely. the crispy onions added a welcome texture contrast to the rest of the dish.  Overall, both dishes were amazing. I also had the passion fruit lemonade. Loving the refills!

Loved the phat rice. Pork belly, more pork, and fried rice. Had some duck dumplings too. But I would come back for that phat rice. It's easy to share the fried rice because of the big portion, but if you truly believe, you can make it your personal fried rice. I would skip the Urbanbelly Ramen. Just because there is pork belly in it, doesn't make it fabulous. I think they went overboard on the broth. Of the dozens and dozens of the other ramen joints, I've never seen this dark cloudy pink broth concoction until eating here. And it didnt taste that good either. Also there was just way to much broth for the amount of noodles given, or maybe they just didn't put enough ramen noodles in the bowl. I'm also not a fan of the whole paying first, and tipping first experience. I mean, I had to pour my own water and if I wanted some more beer, I had to go to the front and order it there, so it took out the whole service experience.
First time having Asian fusion. It was so yummy. So close to my job, I'll def be a regular!!!!
Great Asian fusion spot. Very quick service, pretty good local beer (can) selection. Had the Phat noodles and sweet potatoe dumpling. Both were excellent! Great outdoor seating, very hip place!

First time at this place. They have two sides of the restaurant. One side serves ramen and the other has Asian fusion dishes. I had the short ribs and they were delicious. We also had the lamb buns, which was a very interesting style of the traditional steam pork bun.
I had the phat rice. I wasn't very impressed. The dish had a mushy moisture to it that didn't seem right. I wouldn't return.

Food from here is amazing get the lemon grass chicken you won't regret it!!!! The customer service here is also excellent. You order your food at the counter then they bring it to your table, very fast, I might add! The ramen is also excellent but I would recommend getting the chicken in it instead of the pork!
The interior is well done.  The ramen was very flavorful. Not filling, but then again I eat a lot.

Can't get enough of this place. I come here often with my boyfriend after the gym because we are always hungry and they have a section you can sit in where you food comes out within minutes. Have only had the vegetarian food, but the pea shoot and sweet potato dumplings are something that I consistently crave. Great price considering the location and quality of food. The foam on the beer is so much fun, and cocktails are great too.

The decor was nice but honestly the food was mediocre at best. There were barely any noodles in their so called special food item (urbanbelly ramen) and the broth was way too salty. It was also overpriced. Tried their other dish phat noodles as well and thought that was salty as well. Substituted the udon noodles with rice noodles but it felt like they cooked it with oil for too long causing it to taste mushy, almost like we were eating mush.

Very delicious and unique options. All hot food so a little difficult for summer. They share the space with bellyq. Only complaint were the gnats and giant fly that were all over. The gnats were giant and a concern for an indoor seating location.
I get the Ramen the one that has pork in it. Savory and spicy. It is a bowl of awesomeness.
The pad Thai is fantastic. The rice cakes have a great texture. Also tried the sweet potato dumplings - really good!

Two of us visited this place on a rainy Saturday afternoon. Because of it's location, we managed a parking spot a little far away. They do not take reservations hence we decided to go at noon. To our luck there were only a couple of tables occupied. So we could take our time and browse the menu boards that are up front, as well as go over the fancy, imported beer selection - That was steeply priced. They have a communal seating concept and this "live wall" which is a pretty neat addition. We ordered for a Kirin Pitcher with the frozen foam and beef & cheddar wontons. The wontons were tasty and crisp. For our mains we got the mushroom pho and the ramen jr. Both the dishes were unique in their broths and even for a "jr" serving it was quite a large portion. On the whole a pleasant experience at a very hipster joint. I look forward to seeing what their other joints have in store.

The sweet potato and maple dumplings are amazing!! Their mushrooms pho is also awesome. I love the broth they make it in, super flavorful!   Super fast service and its BYOB on Sundays!  I've heard people don't like the order at the counter part but it's really not too bad as they still serve you. Will try the wicker park location next! :)
Love this place. We have 2 under 2 and there is not too many place where you can actually relax and eat. Great food and great vegan options!

Ordered from Urbanbelly via Grubhub today - the Urbanbelly Pork Belly ramen is quite good! The soup was not at hot as you would get in the store, but it was no problem as I heated it up in the microwave. The broth was pretty good, and the pork belly was delicious. The edamame was pretty good as well. A little bit oily so I had to rinse it off a little, but the flavors were great.

Inside the same building as BellyQ, but a different restaurant.  Tables long and would allow for big groups.  Food was delivered quick, but all other areas of service were sparse.  We tried the Phat Rice, Ramen, and a Pineapple-guava macaroon.  The rice was the best dish, 8/10, tad salty (it is fried rice after all), lemongrass chicken the best of the meats, pork belly very fatty (like 80%), and braised beef was tough and fatty.  The ramen smelled good and had a unique broth flavor, had 2 large pieces of unflavored pork belly (almost devoid of fat, contrary to that in the phat rice), but lacked noodles (extra were $2.50),  Lastly the pineapple-guava macaroon was 90% coconut shavings, and there wasn't enough of the pineapple-guava mixture in the middle to taste any.  Perhaps it was an off-day, but overall not reason enough to return.

I really enjoyed eating here! Their rice bowls are all really good, from what my group was saying) I had the Ramen, which was good, but I don't think I would order it again. The broth/noodle ration was pretty off, and it was the most expensive thing on the menu... so... I feel like their other stuff is better and cheaper. I liked the outdoor dining! Very casual, and nice.
Big fan of Urban Belly.  Dine in and delivery are both great. Perfect go-to restaurant quick eats.

My first time here and eating Ramen. 1) Outside patio is a 5. Its nicely decorated and secluded even though it is located by two busy streets (Ogden/Randolph). Self serve water and utensils are also a nice touch.  2) Service was also good. Prompt service and clean up. No rush to leave and ordering went quickly (they give you a number and bring food to table).  3) Food is OK. I ordered the Pork Belly Ramen and Edamame as appetizer.  The portion of Ramen was very generous and the egg therein was perfect. The Pork Belly was pretty good as well. The overall liquid portion was just ok. I would have preferred it be a little spicier (the chilly sauce did not help).  The Edamame was just ok as well. The portion was pretty small (but ok for the price). The spices were not quite working out. My GF has eaten here before and said that the Edamame was a little off as well, maybe it was just a bad day to have it.  I'll likely come back to try some other choices on the menu.  They have beer and its BYOB on Sundays I believe if you would like to do it.

I really like the ambiance of this place. It is a really nice casual place to get a quick bite. It is right next to belly-Q. I usually get their ramen. I really like their broth. Though, last time it might have been a tad bit salty for my taste. I really like this place a lot and would definitely come back here.

For our final meal in Chicago, we just wanted a little comfort food before heading the the airport. Urbanbelly was convenient and that's where we headed. We ordered our food first and sat down in the restaurant. The seating was community style and just grabbed a table for us and all our luggage. When our food came, it was pipping hot and ready to warm our stomaches. The ramen broth was deliciously savory. The only thing I disliked was the pork bellly, but that's just because I'm not a fan of eating fatty meat. This was great way to end our trip to Chicago.
Fantastic flavor, quality, and representation. I am so happy to have enjoyed two dishes and two appetizers from UrbanBelly and will quickly do so again. This is the best Pad Thai I have ever had!

3 and a half stars!  We were here for dinner on rainy weeknight. The place is really cool and casual with a very urban ambiance. The tables are set up for communal dining. But since it was a week night there wasn't too much of a crowd and we had the whole table to ourselves. We ordered the wheat berry bowl and the pea shoot fried rice and the spiced edamame. I really liked the wheat berry bowl - it was perfectly tangy, sweet, spicy. It tasted great - though was a bit too greasy for my taste. The pea shoot fried rice looked really good but it was too salty. I don't know why a lot of places these days have too much of salt in their food. Too much salt does not mean tasty. The spiced edamame was pretty good as well. The service was good and friendly.

Ordered to go tonight from urban belly and was not impressed. Got the pork and cilantro dumplings which were good. Phat rice was just ok and the pad Thai was weird - pad Thai is supposed to have rice noodles this one had weird shaped rice cake noodles.  The ramen was ok, nothing awesome. Also, very small portions. Probably won't order from here again.

Yelp reviews are about honesty, right? Well, I was honestly disappointed with Urbanbelly. Other Yelp reviews let me down.  When I think of West Town Asian fusion BYOB places, I think of cheap food, decent quality, decent service, with kind of a hipster feel. Well, the only thing UrbanBelly has going for it is the hipster feel. I get it, your building rent is high. But, I hate when places don't give you enough food and I leave hungry. Not only was the food high priced, the beers were really high priced. Even though it may show up in your BYOB search, it is only BYOB for a small window of hours. The cork fee is like $20 otherwise! I got the duck dumplings which other yelpers recommended. I was not impressed. The flavor was actually kind of bland, and I liked the pork dumplings better. Service was also to be desired. You have to go all the way around to the front counter where you ordered it you want anything. And then the guys up there act really annoyed that you are asking them for help! Like hello, water is a basic need. I NEED WATER. I wont be coming back, and would say it's not worth your time either.
The environment looks so cool and beautiful. Food are great. Like everything we ordered. Love this place and will comeback next time for sure.

Food was pretty good, but think it's a bit pricey.  Went for lunch for two and ordered appetizer and two dishes and bill came out to 40 dollars.  I guess it's comparable for the area, but when thinking of getting a ramen and a rice dish, maybe a bit much?  Regardless good food.  Recommend other to try and they can decide for themself

Urbanbelly is the epitome of delicious, trendy and fun. The urban ramen was delicious from the broth to the tender porkbelly to the noodles! It was flavorful with a hint of spice. The pork an cilantro dumplings were excellent. They were soft and drizzled with a balsamic reduction. The service was stellar and the food came out hot. I would highly recommend this establishment.

I come here regularly. The base for the for the Urbanbelly Ramen and Rice Cake is so delicious, I guarantee it's unlike any broth you've had in your life. You won't be disappointed.  The Asian Bolognese use to be one of my favorites too-- until today! I got my order and it was totally different than every other time I had ordered it. There was barely any flavor or spice--the tomato flavor overpowered the dish and there was no 'Hearty Sauce of Ground Pork'--more like crumbs. So disappointing-- I returned it because I thought the chef may have made a mistake...Nope... Turns out the have a NEW Recipe!!! :/ The manager just gave me a brand new dish of the same 'NEW recipe.' Should have given me a refund or a new dish of the menu.  They definitely need to update this description-- no longer accurate-- 'Udon Noodles with Hearty Sauce of Ground Pork, Chinese Black Beans & Sun Dried Tomatoes' The new dish tastes like a bad college version of spaghetti-- 'Udon Noodles with Canned Pasta Sauce'

This one is way better and better priced than BellyQ. Had the phat rice which was really good, the phat noodle I liked way more, and had the urbanbelly ramen which was so tasty. I'm not a pork person so I skipped out on eating too much of it in the ramen, but it tastes just fine without meat. The set up of the restaurant is really nice. You order as soon as you walk in. Then you can sit wherever, on the table they have bowls, utensils, napkins, cups and water ready for you. The food came out quickly. Definitely will be back!

Loved this casual place adjacent to BellyQ last night! I was prompted to come in after watching "The best thing I ever ate" on the Food Network channel. They were doing their spicy episode and their kimchi stew was listed. So first, it is an off the menu item. Second, it's actually not that spicy. BUT.... it is very good! They use their spicy pork ramen broth which is very yummy, and then they add their kimchi to it which adds a little bit of a kick! I recommend it although I am excited to try their ramen next time! Also tried their phat rice which is a fried rice with pineapple, pork, and other yummy things in it!  My husband thoroughly enjoyed our meal, and we cannot wait to come back!

Urbanbelly has won me over.  +They have a good sized menu with many delicious sounding options. However it's not so expansive that it overwhelms you. +After ordering, you can grab a seat at any of their modern yet casual communal tables. Loved the chill atmosphere and also the design of the Urbanbelly dining area....so much so that I weirded out and took photos in front of this grassy, leafy wall. Then they bring your food out to you. +Love the open kitchen where you can stalk Chef Kim doing his thing.  +Food came out really quickly which was great because I was starvvvvvvvin'. +Huge, huge portion. At first I scoffed at paying $17 (incl tip) for my $13 Urbanbelly Ramen---but I take all my cheapass mutterings back! This ramen is making 3 meals for me easily...probably 4. +The Wagyu Beef wontons ($7 for 4) were just alright. They were plated beautifully but they didn't blow me away. However they have some other dumplings I'd love to try in the future....Sweet potato potstickers, I'm looking at you! +Urbanbelly Ramen!!!! Must. Get. I've already raved over the giant size of this dish but now let me rave about the dish itself. Their signature ramen dish has a great balance of spices and flavor that made my urban belly so happy. It was filled with ramen noodles, two huge slabs of pork belly, an egg, and mushrooms all in a semi-creamy and semi-spicy broth. For me, this was total perfection in a ramen. I absolutely loved it. +Once you're done, if you have leftovers, they will take it in the back and wrap it up for you. We had buku leftovers. I've been to BellyQ and loved it so I'm really happy to see the more casual version didn't disappoint.

This rating is based on ramen cravings via takeout. The Urbanbelly Ramen never disappoints. We've also tried the Mushroom Pho, pork dumplings and kimchi. Their broths are so rich and flavorful and even better as leftovers the next day!

Kid friendly - thank you!!!  Phat rice and Ramen were tasty, great portions.  Kiddies crushed two servings of the edamame and chicken rice.  PB&J ice cream and donuts - elegant. Service was amazing and attentive to our needs, we'd go back again.

I am still dreaming about this meal I had over the weekend....it was definitely one for the books! We originally tried going to Belly-Q, but since it was only 4:30 and they weren't opened yet, the hostess suggested that we try their sister restaurant Urban Belly. I am so glad we did! My boyfriend and I ordered way more food than we should have for just the two of us, but we got so excited reading the menu, there were things we just had to try! We both love a good Asian fusion menu, we couldn't resist! We went with the Korean Chicken wings, the Waygu and Cheddar dumplings, the Urbanbelly Ramen with chicken instead of pork, and the Asian Bolognese. The chicken wings were the weakest, but they were still yummy! There was a creamy horseradish sauce to dip them in that was very flavorful.  The dumplings also had a similar horseradish sauce on top of them, which gave them the perfect amount of spice. They were light, crispy, and delicious. Next, the ramen. The broth had a great flavor to it, and they even made it with chicken per our request. I was surprised because usually a chicken based broth falls weak on the flavor, but theirs certainly did not. The noodles had the perfect amount of bite to them also. Lastly, the Bolognese. This menu item was a thing of my dreams. It was truly amazing!!! They took their perfectly cooked, silky udon noodles, and topped them off with a delicious pork ragu. The sauce wasn't your traditional Bolognese though, it had an Asian kick to it that was unworldly. I will definitely be coming back for this dish! The only reason this isn't getting the full 5 stars is because of the service. We asked someone working for a ramen spoon when they dropped off the food, and were told he'd be right back with it. Instead, he proceeded to walk back and forth past us plenty of times without any spoon.

My experience with Urbanbelly was pretty out of the ordinary. While in Chicago for work, my colleagues/friends and I came to Urbanbelly for dinner. Because it was Superbowl Sunday, one of my associates asked if the restaurant had a TV (I couldn't care less about sports bowl). The manager was within earshot. And I guess because there were so few patrons in the restaurant, he offered up their tasting lounge for us to watch the game. To which I asked if it meant we would be ordering from their sister restaurant, BellyQ. He responded by handing me one of each menu and said, "feel free to order from either menu." Talk about accommodating! And really, I don't like to be catered to. The manager really went out of his way though, and I'm sure it was because it was such a slow night. Regardless, he didn't have to. He chose to. And we were very, very appreciative. Immediately, this was a really good experience. But then the food started to arrive, and a really good experience became a FANTASTIC experience. So much so, that I'll have to write a separate review for the BellyQ menu items I had. Let's start with the dumplings: I don't know which I enjoyed more, the duck & pho dumpling or the pork and cilantro. Both were very unique. I expected the duck dumplings to be heavy, but they're really not. And mind you, I'm one of those people for whom cilantro can be a little overwhelming. But the pork dumplings were delicious too.  What really blew me away though was the "asian bolognese". This was a heavier, more dense dish, naturally. But it still wasn't as heavy as the traditional bolognese I find in most restaurants. It was a very interesting spin. I think it's because of the udon noodles. But the combination of pork, black bean sauce, and tomatoes really makes this dish stand out. Long after I was full, I couldn't bare to let the bolognese go to waste. When I set foot on, or even near, Chicago soil again, I'll be making a b-line for Urbanbelly.

I thought that Urban Belly was amazing! Walk up, order your delight (get the beef and pineapple) and sit down to a cozy atmosphere.  Grab a CHANG beer, it's what we drank when I was in Thailand in November!! Gotta do it!!  Prices are average, maybe a little high but very worth it!! Would totally come back!

Delicious food and a well designed setting. The duck is cooked to perfection and a must have whenever I go. I go here for meetings often and appreciate being able to sit at a high table when doing so. The art and lights are eye catchers and the walls are alive. Great place for a lunch of date night.

We came to check out their ramen and must have misunderstood Urbanbelly's concept. It is not a Japanese restaurant or a Korean restaurant, but rather some sort of fusion. The ramen did not have any sort of identity and was really lacking in variety of ingredients. It did however have a very juicy and nicely seared pork belly. Otherwise the ingredients were small and not full of variety. The decor was cool tho lol.

I thought this place was amazing. They're not entirely vegetarian, but the options that they had were delicious such as the Pho and the Sweet Potato Dumplings. Their Edamame was unique too. I liked the ambiance and the communal tables and our waitress was ever so gracious in finding us a table during a busy dinner rush.

Awesome casual spot for something exotic --think duck dumplings, lemongrass and kimchi...-- but inexpensive and delicious.  I've had the rice and salad bowl with ground chicken twice - outstanding! You get steamed jasmine rice with arugula, pickled vegetables & the most perfectly cooked soft boiled egg on top. The flavors are sooooo gooood.  Cool warehousey space.  Great for a group.  Good beer too.
Lemongrass Chicken Fried Rice and Pad Thai are excellent. Affordable, quick service, and gluten free marked.

meh... the hype is loud, but my experience was mediocre and over-priced. Too many other great ramen and asian places in Chicago; and too many amazing restaurants on Randolph to eat here (or at least eat here more than once).

Loved the food and the Kirin!  Had the Pork Belly Ramen, Duck dumplings & a side of Kimchi.  Fast-fast service!!!!! We didn't realize when we walked in that it was 2 concepts in 1.  Urban Belly is "quick service" whereas BellyQ is "full service."  We were told of the 2nd concept after ordering & paying.    Staff was friendly, prompt & the restaurant was clean.  Will definitely return to try BellyQ.

New favorite lunch spot! The menu is simple and delicious, with options for dumplings, fried rice, ramen, and more! Craft beer & specialty items are also available for sale.  When you walk in, you order at a counter and take a number to a table in the seating area. When you turn the corner, there are large tables equipped with silverware, Asian style condiments, and carafes of water, but even more amazing is the vertical garden! It adds life to the room and made the dining experience complete. Our food was brought out from the open kitchen as it became ready, which was quick!  The duck dumplings were incredible, especially with a mixture of the two house condiments on the table.  I ordered the half house ramen, thinking I'd just have something light... WRONG! I couldn't even finish it, but God knows I tried! It was creamy and flavorful, with a large piece of tender pork marinating in the broth.  My boyfriend ordered a special with a curry zing! Again, tender meat, fresh veggies, and large noodles. Completely different flavor than the ramen, but equally delicious!  The place was clean, our water was kept full, the staff was friendly. Can't wait to go back once the snow has melted so that I can sit on their patio.  :)

hidden gem. spacious. ordered the phat noodle - curry udon, pork belly, brisket, lemongrass chicken, and napa cabbage. dishes were comforting and flavorful. definitely give this place a try! will come back again and try other things on the menu! check out the picture i posted.

Phat rice.  That is all.  Well, not really. My friend has the mushroom pho and it was really rich and savory. Didn't even taste meatless! Service was great. Everyone was really welcoming and attentive. Love the living wall too!

Despite having family around the table as we speak from UK, I had to call the restaurant to congratulate them and write this review with the flavours still in our mouths.  Will try and keep it short, drove past urban belly/belly q a hundred times and tonight we decided to order a take it from urban belly. Ordered every dumpling, pad Thai and phat rice. Travelled Asia 5 times so far and sampled some of the best asian cuisine in America and we have NEVER encountered flavours so authentic than here. My parents from UK are fussy eaters and we are all sat round in awe of this place. This is my first ever review and signed up to write this one. I guarantee this is the best in Chicago hands down. Thank you Daniel and Christine the manager for welcoming my feedback so graciously inviting us to meet the chefs on our next visit. We will take you up on that!  10/10. Thank you.

I have to honestly say I've tried to like this place, but it feels like whoever runs is is dead set on making sure they close. First, I called up to place an order and was informed that although they close an hour from the time I called they were going to close early (because hey why not). Second time, I picked up and they forgot to include noodles with the Ramen. Third attempt, I called to get delivery and they directed me to their site that told me that they don't deliver to me (I live .5 miles away). I'm just gonna go ahead and say forget this place and take my business to the handful of the other spots that can keep their act together.

Yelp came to the rescue again!  It is such a useful tool when trying to find things - specifically food - when traveling! We got there about 10 minutes after them opening for lunch, so we were the only ones there for about 15 minutes, but that definitely didn't last long. We ordered sweet potato and maple dumplings, spiced edamame, phat rice, and wheat berry bibimbap.  There's not a single thing to complain about. They have family style seating with forks, chopsticks, bottled water, napkins, and sauces on the table... you only need to get up for the restrooms. The sweet potato and maple dumplings were amazing.  I am not usually a fan of maple, but they were not overly sweet.. perfect compliment to the sweet potato. The spiced edamame was a fantastic surprise... I always enjoy edamame, but the Szechuan peppercorns, coriander, and fennel make this dish a symphony in your mouth. The phat rice!  Oh my geez!  This was fantastic and very filling!  It was so overwhelmingly flavorful while not being overpowering.  I would definitely order this again! Lastly, the bibimbop.. my husband was thoroughly pleased... I wasn't able to try too much as I was stuffed from all my food, but it was very flavorful.  This was the talk of the day while we were going out and about. I take it back, I do have one complaint... why is this place NOT in Ohio?!
The best asian fusion place i've ever been to! Nice interiors. I drive 40 mins to eat their food.

I've been to both Urbanbelly and Belly Q now, and the casual side is a-okay, but not amazing. Urbanbelly is the more "order and grab a seat" style annex to Belly Q. It's a great, casual space with communal seating and order tags adjacent to the fancier Belly Q restaurant and bar. I was pretty excited for their Phat Rice and Rice Cake dishes--Phat Rice with 3 types of pork and Rice Cake Soup with chicken katsu in a spicy tomato-based broth. Although these were unique, strongly flavored, and very filling, I felt that the combinations were a little over-ambitious and consequently sloppy. The Phat Rice had 3 different kinds of meat, all uniquely flavored and strong. When added together, it just became distracting and a little overwhelming. The Rice Cake Soup was promising at first, but a little too salty for my taste and the mix of fish balls and chicken katsu was odd to me.  Overall, average experience. But I'd go back.

Our first time here and we picked an absolute winner. We started with theDuck & Pho spiced dumplings. Our meal (Asian Bolognese) showed up very quick. Which is something you want when heading to a Blackhawks game.
The most terrible chicken wings I've ever tasted in my life disgusting who ever came up with the sauce for them must have no tongue they went straight in the garbage
This place is amazing!  Unique asian fusion...never tasted such blends before.  If you are in Chicago, its a must try.   Love this place!

Went in on a Sunday early evening and no problem finding a spot for two and a child. There is free two hour street parking right across randolph. The steamed pork pot stickers were very tasty. We also ordered the beef wontons which were amazing. I had the ramen which has a nice kick to it. If you finish ramen they will refill your noodles for $2.50. The pork belly was juicy and crispy. My wife had the rice cake. It has fish balls in case you don't like fish. we ordered the kids noodles for my son. The noodles smelled a little fishy but my son loved them. I had the $3 drafts. They automatically add the icy froth on top.

They serve Asian fusion style food. I had their version of Pad Thai and Duck Dumplings. It is similar to a lot of the Asian fusion places here in California so it was not that special to me but I do appreciate the flavors and the reasonable pricing for what you get.

Don't eat here...or anywhere near here.  I was basically robbed while eating at Urbanbelly. I thought I would meet a friend in a new part of the city for lunch.   Parking is a bit of a challenge in the area but I found street parking right behind the restaurant.  I confirmed with the Urbanbelly hostess about my parking location and she told me I should be fine.  It turns out that a neighboring business has 100-200 cars a month towed from that street, and I returned to find my car towed.  The owner bragged about it to me.  He also watched me park there and made no effort to explain that I shouldn't park there.  There was a banner 50 yards away but the signage was completely inadequate and confusing....nothing like I have seen anywhere else. This was complete entrapment and any reasonable person would park exactly as I did. I split an Uber with another Urbanbelly customer and we paid $218.50 each to get our cars back.  As we reviewed what happened to both of us, it was pretty clear that this was a scam. Not worth it. Go somewhere else.

ehhh... - Lychee lemonade tasted nothing like lychee... - Not your traditional dumpling...had way too much cream cheese - There are better ramen spot in the neighborhood. - If you're looking for traditional dumplings and ramen, this place isn't for you. - Nothing memorable...

This was really good food!  We had the Ramen and Phat Rice...both excellent dishes!  The Ramen did have cilantro in it though (not sited on the menu), a tip for my fellow cilantro haters.  Service was friendly.  You order at the counter and they bring everything over to you.  I would suggest that knives be added to the silverware kits.  There were several times my eating companion and I wished for a knife.

I wrote this review before we even have our food just because how amazing they accommodated us. It was raining in morning so they closed their patio. However, when we showed up with our dog, they had no problem with opening up their patio right away to sit us. Such a way to keep their customer.

Came here with my sister on a nice day so we sat outside. They had water for you to serve yourself if you do choose to sit out. She ordered ramen with katsu chicken that was delicious! I ordered some appetizer wings that had a different taste than the regular hooters or wing stop. It was tangy and flavorful,but I wouldn't order them again. My plate was the lemon grass chicken and they serve you enough to get full. (I enjoy a place that puts a lot on my plate)There's waitresses that come give you your order and you'll see every now and then. I would come back to try some more things off the menu. Definitely a place to come and try!

Seems like a popular spot, but a disappointment in my opinion. If anyone is looking for ramen, do not go to urbanbelly for it. In my opinion, urbanbelly is more for vegetarian or vegan. Don't get hot tea unless you want to pay $3-4 for a super miniature version of a teapot. Ordered wings as appetizer. Tried a vegetarian bowl because nothing else seemed appealing to eat. My bf ordered the ramen. Ordered a piece of macaroon. One of the worst meals ever had. If you plan to go, don't plan on it being amazing since the other reviews make it seem to be.

This was my first time trying Ramen! Urban belly did not disappoint. Although I may question the authenticity of the dish,  it was really good. Besides the ramen, I tried the sweet potato dumplings and the Phat Rice. The phat Rice was amazeballs, the rice was cooked to perfection. I would most certainly recommend this place
Had lemongrass chicken and frozen beer . Yumm ! Go ahead and try this restaurant !

I have somewhat turned into a ramen snob. I love my ramen and I like them flavourful and big. While this ramen was big, the flavour simply failed to impress. We also tried the fried rice which too was okay at best. Been here twice and both times left unimpressed.  My friends have reviewed BellyQ favourably so next time I'm hopping next door to BellyQ.

Now for people who have never gone to urban belly, it's a causal dinning place where you order at a counter, they give you a number and bring out your food. Next door is belly U where it's a fancy sit down full service restaurant which shares the same kitchen as urban belly. Both have different menus, urban belly is slightly cheaper.  We went to urban belly for the ramen, and dumplings. They allowed us to sit in the far back room of Belly U for the TV. The guys wanted to watch the Sunday night food ball game. Also there's no other TV in there but that one.  Urban belly ramen was by far the best I've ever had, large portions too. We also had the pork and cilantro dumplings, wow, those were great! Also try their gummy bears up front. Thank you to the staff for allowed us to seat on the couches in the very back just for the guys to watch their football game.

I've had nearly everything on their menu - it's all great! Love their unique take on pad thai and their mushroom pho is spicy and delicious too. Also, you must try the beer with the frozen beer topping. I wish I could take a cup to go. So good!

Located close to Union park and only a couple blocks from the Ashland pink/green line is the brainchild of Chicago chef Bill Kim.  His first restaurant in the city, Urbanbelly is now one of 3 restaurant with his trademark "belly" in the name.  Look no further than right next door where you will find BellyQ, Chef Kim's take on korean bbq.  While BellyQ and Urbanbelly share the same kitchen and a familiar cuisine, the similarities end there.  Urbanbelly provides a casual, price conscious, friendly environment with a focus on starches.  Here you will find the menu split by starch: dumplings, grains, and noodles.  Dumplings are $7 for 4. Rice dishes and noodle dishes range from $9-$13.  A pitcher of Kirin beer was $10 or $3 for a pint.  If you happen to partake in "a la card chicago" you will find that both Urbanbelly and BellyQ are in the deck of cards.   I came here for two reasons: I happened to be visiting the Randolph Street Market just a block down the road (awesome btw), and the $10 card to Urbanbelly.  I had heard good things about it, and nothing gets my stomach growling like Asian food.  Everything on the menu looks good.  My girlfriend and I ordered a pitcher of beer, the Duck and Pho spice dumplings to start, and then I ordered the Phat noodle and she ordered the Rice cake noodle as our entrees.  Ordering is done at the counter, and the ambiance is modern and inviting.  Service is fantastic as we got our food in about 5-10 minutes.  As food goes, we liked the Duck dumplings the best by far.  The dumplings were crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside, and were perfectly paired with the cucumber and a little house made hot sauce.  The Phat noodle was disappointing.  The flavor felt like something was missing, and the chicken was dry and tasteless.  The pork belly was my favorite part of the dish.  I wouldn't order it again.  The Rice cake noodle was quite good.  The broth was flavorful and spicy.  The chicken katsu was well cooked.  The mango in the broth was a great idea.  It's a bit on the spicy side so be careful if spice isn't your thing.  My only complaint was the rice cake seemed a bit too much.   Location: 4 stars Environment: 4 stars Service: 5 stars.  The food came out in about 5-10 minutes Taste: 3 stars. see above Price: 4 stars Menu selection: 4 stars. Plenty of meat vs veggie dishes.  Lots of different starch options. Overall: 3.5 stars Will I return: Yes
Love this spot, been a dozen plus times with multiple groups and everyone is blown away.  the counter service is great and it is affordable given the quality and location.

Very helpful staff, delicious food and attractive decor. The Chinese Rice Cakes in the Pad Thai were interesting in the best way! The Sweet Potato Dumplings were also really tasty. Imani was very knowledgeable and answered all our questions with patience. Check this place out!

Came here with a friend during a lull and ordered the Phat Rice. Wasn't sure how I felt about pineapple in my dish, but count me as a fan now. It was pretty damn good! I'm a picky eater and this helped me push my food boundaries- always a plus in my book.
We are vegetarians and ordered in through grub hub. The food came in super quick and was soooo yummy.  We had the edamame, sweet potato dumplings and the mushroom pho noodles.  Highly recommend it.
Words cannot explain how much I love their lemongrass chicken rice. Delivery is always super quick also!  Absolutely love this place, and I highly recommend the lemongrass chicken rice or phat rice.

I've been to BellyQ a few times and found it to be somewhat meh, so I wasn't expecting Urban Belly to be that different. However, I was pleasantly surprised! Urban Belly shares a space and a kitchen with BellyQ but is more casual. You order at the counter and then sit in the communal table space behind the counter. I had the sweet potato and maple dumpings (delicious, especially with bacon!) and the duck and pho dumpings, which were okay. I also had some of the UrbanBelly ramen, which was in a coconut milk/curry type broth. It was very good, though not very big (the bowl was big, but the actual ingredients were a bit sparse). I finished with the PB&J ice cream, which I've had before at BellyQ. I would come here again!

Came here for the first time after living in Chicago for 3 years and I'm sad that I won't be back for awhile since I've recently moved out of Chicago.  If you haven't been here, you order first, pay and then get a number and sit where ever you like. Ordered the phat rice, beef and horseradish dumplings and a junior ramen bowl. Everything was deeeelicious!!! So much flavor in each dish. My bf talks about the phat rice and how he craves it. We can't wait to visit Chicago just to eat here again! I definitely recommend this restaurant. The atmosphere is super casual and the decor is simple yet cute. Plus it's in the west loop and you can't beat an area full of different restaurants and bars.

I really enjoyed the food here.  We got a number of things:  beef dumplings, lamb buns, sticky rice, kimchi potato salad, coconut grits, kale salad, catfish and chicken.  Everything was good, standouts for me were the coconut grits and the lamb buns.  Kale salad was the weakest dish.  They are serving up some nice and complex flavors. The dishes are well-composed. Dessert:  fresh house made donuts with jam.  Delicious! I plan to return the next time I am in Chicago.

Went here last night with a group of about 12 people. They were very accommodating with our group size and there is plenty of seating! It's great for a group because you order at a counter instead of at the table which makes paying painless. I ordered the rice cake noodle dish and it was so delicious! There was so much food though- the leftovers will keep me satisfied for at least 2 more meals. Also delicious were the pork and cilantro dumplings with soy balsamic sauce. Will definitely go again

I ordered from Urbanbelly on a Wednesday night using Grubhub. The order came in about 45 minutes, which was okay, although I thought it would be a bit faster. I ordered the Phat Rice and the Pad Thai. The Pad Thai was, well, not what I was expecting. Although it did say rice cakes on Grubhub, I assumed that the rice cakes were an addition to the typical noodles in a Pad Thai. I assumed wrong! I received just the rice cakes with sauce, toppings, and grilled (maybe?) shrimp tossed inside. Nevertheless, the food was great. The rice cakes were surprisingly delicious, the shrimps were large and plump, and all the additional toppings like peanuts and garlic complemented the dish well. For $13, the portion was tiny but it was delicious, and I guess I can justify the price...a bit. The Phat Rice was larger compared to the Pad Thai. The rice was cooked just right (al dente, for those wondering), the other little things didn't get in the way of eating, and again, the portion was good (but not great!) for $13. The meats (ground chicken, pork belly, and braised beef short ribs) were definitely on point. I didn't notice the chicken too much because it was ground up and mixed with the rice, but the pork belly, which was a bit dry, was soft and tasty and the short rib was chewy but had a melt-in-your-mouth texture. All three meats had a great taste, although the Chicken was just a tad bit bland. There were ample amounts of meat compared to the rice, and by the end, I found myself debating whether or not I should order again the next day. Overall, a very delicious dish. Solid 5 stars for food, but knocking one star off for rather small portions and big prices. So far the best food I had in Chicago without stepping outside the hotel!

Another date night, another excuse to try something new in the city! We LOVE trying the restaurants on W. Randolph (it's the new up and coming restaurant row!), and we do love our Asian fusion. It gives me ideas on what I can try at home with whatever Korean cuisine background I have (being Korean and all). We were initially confused because we both had no idea that there were two separate restaurants. Urbanbelly is the more "casual" one and BellyQ is the "sit-down menu" one. After looking over both menus, we decided we were in a more casual mood and ordered our food at the counter. They give you a number to take to your table and bring out the food to you when it's ready. It was a GORGEOUS evening, so we sat outside in the patio area. LOVE the urban mural on the wall with the stringed lights for added decor. Really gives me that Chicago summer patio vibe and it's wonderful. The inside is beautiful too. They have a wall with lush green plants and industrial-type lighting with glass that makes it look like huge light bulbs. I am probably not describing it well, so just take a look at the photos of the interior decor to get a better idea. :) Btw, make sure to order their Kirin Ichiban on draft; it is on. point. They top it off with this beer slushie that is just icy enough to keep the beer beneath nice and cold. Are you listening? It's a BEER. SLUSHIE. on top of my already awesome refreshing beer. You guys are taking this to whole other level, yo. And I love it. We've been on a mission to try ramen places in Chicago to compare and find our top favorite. So, of course we ordered the Urbanbelly Ramen ($13) which are the ramen noodles with braised pork belly, mushrooms & an egg. Let me start with the broth: If Tom Yum and Ramen had a broth baby, it would be this dish. There was a slight sweetness to it (like Tom Yum) and there was also lemongrass, cilantro and mushrooms, all of which can be found in Tom Yum soup. Yet, it was thick like ramen broth, and slightly spicy. Talk about Asian fusion, right? The best of Japanese ramen and Thai soup! The noodles were not the absolute best that I've had, but they were still fairly good. I just couldn't wrap my head around eating a bowl of ramen that had lemongrass and cilantro in it. The egg is added whole (NOT cut in half like most places) because the yolk is runny. When you cut open that thing, get ready for some beautiful egg porn with the ooey-gooey yolk oozing out into your broth. The absolute best part of this dish was the PORK: I mean. WOW. Thick cut (and I mean THICKY THICK, like Beyonce's jelly) pork belly meat, braised to perfection. The outside was perfectly crispy, and it was so tender and juicy, melt-in-your-mouth deliciousness on the inside. I would order the ramen bowl JUST for the pork. Out of all the pork that I've had in my ramen, this one certainly stole the show. I shall crown thee as our Royal Ramen Pork Belly, behold thy Oink King! We also ordered the Phat Rice because of the reviews that we read here on Yelp (thanks, fellow Yelpers).
